awd_titl_txt: DISSERTATION RESEARCH:   Investigating the evolution of phalangerid marsupials in Sulawesi by incorporating morphology, molecular phylogenomics and biogeographical modeling
awd_abstract_narration:
The island of Sulawesi has long been recognized for its highly distinctive and endemic vertebrate fauna; however, scientists have not been able to determine how or when many of these animals arrived on the island or what drove their remarkable diversification. This deficit of understanding has been due in part to uncertainty surrounding relationships among the animals themselves and the difficulty of reconstructing the island's highly complex geological history. For many taxa, intra-island diversification patterns remain unclear due to a lack of sufficient geographic sampling. This study will evaluate the temporal and geographic patterns of colonization and intra-island diversification of terrestrial mammals on Sulawesi by using cuscus marsupials as a model system. Reconstructing the evolutionary relationships among cuscuses across this region will help elucidate the historical biogeography of Sulawesi. This research will significantly broaden the professional and technical development of an early career female scientist, who will also train and co-advise an undergraduate student.  

This project will test the hypothesis that microplate tectonics during the formation of Sulawesi and habitat fragmentation in the Pleistocene drove diversification in the Ailuropinae (Phalangeridae, Marsupialia). Extensive inter- and intra-island sampling with be achieved by using existing museum collections and novel methods of extracting ancient DNA. The researchers will incorporate traditional morphological techniques to distinguish and describe taxa along with phylogenomic methods to reconstruct their evolutionary relationships.  Biogeographical modeling will then be used to assess the likelihood of different geographical speciation scenarios. Using these results as a framework, the researchers will then produce a taxonomic revision of the subfamily.

por.por_cntn:
Southeast Asia contains extraordinary biological diversity, which has been shaped by the region's complex geological and climatic history. By studying the effects of tectonic and environmental change on the evolution of species in the region, we can improve our understanding of the processes that produced the rich biodiversity of the tropics. Island systems in particular are valuable natural experiments because colonization events are rare and diversification within them is common. Within Southeast Asia, the Indonesian island of Sulawesi is especially important for biodiversity research because of its unique species and highly complex formation. Sulawesi has never been connected to a continent, and formed as a result of the fusion of several island fragments 5-2 million years ago. The island has long been recognized for its highly distinctive species; however, there has been historical confusion surrounding the origin and diversification of these species. Recent research has provided insights into the formation of the island and its colonization. However, patterns and processes of diversification on the island are still unclear for most groups, because few studies incorporate island-wide sampling.

In this study, we aimed to use genetic and morphological data from museum specimens to gain an understanding of the timing and geographical patterns of diversification in the marsupial subfamily Ailuropinae, a group commonly called cuscuses. The Ailuropinae comprises two genera and four described species: Strigocuscus celebensis, Strigocuscus sangirensis, Ailurops ursinus, and Ailurops melanotis. We focused on cuscuses because they are broadly distributed in Sulawesi and colonized the island early in its formation, giving us the opportunity to understand how the island's geological history shaped the evolutionary history of the group.

We tested four hypotheses: 1) Analyzing the size and shape of Strigocuscus and Ailurops skulls will show distinct groups that align with currently recognized species, and no undescribed morphological diversity will be discovered, 2) DNA sequences will reveal distinct groups and diversity not reflected by skull morphology, 3) DNA analyses will reveal that Strigocuscus and Ailurops share similar patterns and timing of diversification, because their evolution was shaped by colonization and subsequent isolation on island fragments during the formation of Sulawesi, and 4) Strigocuscus and Ailurops individuals will form distinct genetic groups within Areas of Endemism (AoEs), 7 regions in Sulawesi defined by shared geographical distribution of genetic diversity across multiple vertebrate species.  

After measuring 67 skulls and using ancient DNA methods to sequence mitochondrial genomes from 33 museum specimens, we found that for Ailurops, morphological groups match our expectations, with two groups corresponding to described species, and one group representing the montane subspecies A. ursinus furvus. However, our mitochondrial sequence data show a different pattern: within A. ursinus, there are two groups that do not correspond to species, and A. u. furvus specimens do not group together. This means that specimens identified as A. u. furvus, with thick fur and large skulls, probably evolved separately in response to two mountain formation events.

Our morphological dataset shows 4 major groups within S. celebensis, 2 of which don't align with described species or subspecies. Mitochondrial sequence groupings match morphological groups. This suggests that there are unrecognized species or subspecies within Strigocuscus. S. sangirensis is distinct, but only one specimen is represented in our data.  

Contrary to our prediction, patterns and timing of diversification in Ailurops and Strigocuscus are different. This means that although the two genera were exposed to the same conditions during the formation of Sulawesi, they show different early evolutionary histories. This could be due differences in dispersal abilities, or it could indicate that dispersal events were random and cannot be predicted by Sulawesi's geological history. Finally, geographical distribution of mitochondrial sequence groups in both Ailurops and Strigocuscus aligns with AoEs. This means that despite their different early evolutionary histories, both genera were shaped by recent events in Sulawesi's geologic or climatic past that resulted in these shared geographical distribution patterns. Our next steps will be will be to sequence nuclear ultraconserved element DNA, and compare our results from mitochondrial data to those generated with nuclear DNA.

These results have been shared with the scientific community through 5 presentations at scientific meetings, and 4 manuscripts are currently being prepared for publication. Our findings have also been shared with the general public through outreach and education events at the Smithsonian Conservation Biology Institute, National Zoo, and National Museum of Natural History. This project has provided extensive professional development and training opportunities for the co-PI, a female graduate student, in the fields of phylogenomics and bioinformatics. It has also provided training and research experience for 5 female interns from groups underrepresented in science that were co-mentored by the co-PI. This project has not only advanced museum-based phylogenomic research, but also advanced the goal of engaging diverse members of society in science, including the general public and underserved undergraduate communities currently underrepresented in STEM.

 


Last Modified: 09/28/2019
Modified by: Lillian D Parker
